description.raw:
We've seen occasional failures on sensor noise tests that look like they're due to low-probability, but entirely possible, sampling results.  For sensors with Gaussian noise models, we test that samples fall within 3-sigma of the expected mean, which should happen [99.7% of the time](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Normal_distribution#Standard_deviation_and_tolerance_intervals).  But that means that we should expect those tests to fail 0.3% of the time.

This pull request makes the test results deterministic by first setting to a known value the seed used by Gazebo's random-number generator.  It shouldn't matter which seed we use, as long as it's one for which the tests pass.  The tests already internally collect and average many samples before applying the statistical tests.

This should also be merged to default.

For sensors with Gaussian noise models, we test that samples fall within 3-sigma of the expected mean, which should happen 99.7% of the time. But that means that we should expect those tests to fail 0.3% of the time.

This pull request makes the test results deterministic by first setting to a known value the seed used by Gazebo's random-number generator. It shouldn't matter which seed we use, as long as it's one for which the tests pass. The tests already internally collect and average many samples before applying the statistical tests.
